statements.name: PROC CAUSALMED
statements.description: The CAUSALMED procedure estimates causal mediation effects from observational data. In causal mediation analysis, there are four main variables of interest: † o an outcome variable Y o a treatment variable T that is hypothesized to have direct and indirect causal effects on the outcome variable Y (in epidemiology, a treatment variable is also known as an exposure, denoted as A) o a mediator variable M that is hypothesized to be causally affected by the treatment variable T and that itself has a direct effect on the outcome variable Y o set of pretreatment or background covariates that confound the observed relationships among Y, T, and M

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the level 1 – p for constructing confidence intervals. By default, p = 0.05, which corresponds to 1 – p = 95% confidence intervals.

arguments.name: CASECONTROL
arguments.description: Requests an analysis for a case-control study. When you specify this option, PROC CAUSALMED fits a mediator model by using only observations for subjects in the control group.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains the raw data. If the DATA= option is omitted, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: Syntax: DECOMP<=i> requests various decompositions of the total effect. By default, several two- and three-way decompositions and a four-way decomposition are computed. When you specify 2, 3, or 4 for i, decompositions up to an i-way decomposition are computed.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Sorts the levels of the binary outcome and the binary mediator variables in reverse of the specified order.

arguments.name: NLOPTIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies options for the nonlinear optimization methods if you are applying the multivariate adaptive regression splines algorithm to generalized linear models. You can specify the following options:
arguments.help: NLOPTIONS=ABSCONV= | ABSTOL= | ABSFCONV= | ABSFTOL= | ABSGCONV= | ABSGTOL= | FCONV= | FTOL= | GCONV= | GTOL= | HESSIAN= | MAXFUNC= | MAXITER= | MAXIT= | MAXTIME= | MINITER= | MINIT= | TECHNIQUE=

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses all displayed output.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: Displays all output tables.

arguments.name: PMEDMOD
arguments.description: Displays parameter estimates for the mediator model.

arguments.name: POUTCOMEMOD
arguments.description: Displays parameter estimates for the outcome model.

arguments.name: PSHORT
arguments.description: Displays only the basic modeling information and the summary of effects. When you specify this option, you can also display the effect decomposition table by specifying the DECOMP option.

arguments.name: PSUMMARY
arguments.description: Displays only a summary of effects. When you specify this option, you can also display the effect decomposition table by specifying the DECOMP option.

arguments.name: RORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of the outcome variable.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Order of appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: External formatted value, except for numeric variables that have no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Descending frequency count. Levels that have the most observations come first in the order.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance for testing the singularity of a matrix, where tolerance must be between 0 and 1. The default tolerance is 1E7 times the machine precision.

arguments.name: THREADS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of threads (n) for analytic computations and overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS.

statements.name: BOOTSTRAP
statements.description: The BOOTSTRAP statement requests bootstrap estimates of standard errors and bootstrap confidence intervals for various effects and percentages of total effects.

arguments.name: BOOTCI=
arguments.description: Computes bootstrap-based confidence intervals for the effects and percentages of effects, and displays them in the "Summary of Effects" table.

arguments.name: NBOOT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of bootstrap sample data sets (replicates), where n is between 50 and 10,000. By default, n=1000.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Provides the seed that initializes the random number stream for generating the bootstrap sample data sets (replicates).

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement with PROC NETWORK to obtain separate analyses of observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified is used. If your input data set is not sorted in ascending order, use one of the following alternatives: • Sort the data by using the SORT procedure with a similar BY statement. • Specify the NOTSORTED or DESCENDING option in the BY statement for the NETWORK procedure. The NOTSORTED option does not mean that the data are unsorted but rather that the data are arranged in groups (according to values of the BY variables) and that these groups are not necessarily in alphabetical or increasing numeric order. • Create an index on the BY variables by using the DATASETS procedure (in Base SAS software).

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: The NOTSORTED option does not mean that the data are unsorted but rather that the data are arranged in groups (according to values of the BY variables) and that these groups are not necessarily in alphabetical or increasing numeric order.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names one or more classification variables to be used as explanatory variables in the analysis.

arguments.name: CPREFIX=
arguments.description: Uses at most the first n characters of a CLASS variable name in creating names for the corresponding design variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sort order of the CLASS variables.

arguments.name: LPREFIX=
arguments.description: Uses at most the first n characters of a CLASS variable name in creating labels for the corresponding design variables.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (blanks for character variables and ., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables) as valid values for the CLASS variables.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of CLASS variables.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Sorts the levels in their order of appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Sorts the levels by external formatted values, except for numeric variables that have no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) values.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Sorts the levels by descending frequency count. Levels that have more observations come earlier in the order.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Sorts the levels by an unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: REF=
arguments.description: Specifies a level of the CLASS variable to be put at the end of the list of levels.

arguments.name: TRUNCATE
arguments.description: Specifies the length (n) of variable values to use in determining the CLASS variable levels.

statements.name: COVAR
statements.description: The COVAR statement specifies the effects of covariates in a causal mediation analysis.

statements.name: EVALUATE
statements.description: You use the EVALUATE statement to specify variable levels or values for evaluating various effects. In the assignments, you can specify one or more of the following variable levels: o the control and treatment levels for computing all effects o the mediator level for computing the controlled direct effect o the covariate levels for evaluating various conditional causal effects Each assignment is of the form var-key=value-key where var-key specifies a variable and value-key is either its numerical value, its character value, or a keyword (such as MEAN) that generates a value from the variable.

arguments.name: _CONTROL=
arguments.description: Specifies the control level of the treatment variable, where varname represents the actual treatment variable name.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Assigns the first level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Assigns the last level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Assigns the maximum variable value (denoted as max) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Assigns the mean variable value (denoted as mean) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Assigns the minimum variable value (denoted as min) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MODE
arguments.description: Assigns the modal level of the corresponding class variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Assigns the numerical value in the assignment, where value represents a fixed number. If you use the SD option, the measurement scale of the numerical value refers to the measurement scale of the standardized variable.

arguments.name: level
arguments.description: Assigns the level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key, where level represents an actual character level of the variable.

arguments.name: _MEDIATOR
arguments.description: Specifies the controlled level of the mediator variable, where varname represents the actual mediator variable name.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Assigns the first level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Assigns the last level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Assigns the maximum variable value (denoted as max) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Assigns the mean variable value (denoted as mean) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Assigns the minimum variable value (denoted as min) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MODE
arguments.description: Assigns the modal level of the corresponding class variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Assigns the numerical value in the assignment, where value represents a fixed number. If you use the SD option, the measurement scale of the numerical value refers to the measurement scale of the standardized variable.

arguments.name: level
arguments.description: Assigns the level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key, where level represents an actual character level of the variable.

arguments.name: _TREATMENT
arguments.description: Specifies the treatment level of the treatment variable, where varname represents the actual treatment variable name.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Assigns the first level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Assigns the last level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Assigns the maximum variable value (denoted as max) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Assigns the mean variable value (denoted as mean) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Assigns the minimum variable value (denoted as min) of the corresponding numerical variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: MODE
arguments.description: Assigns the modal level of the corresponding class variable that is specified in the var-key.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: Assigns the numerical value in the assignment, where value represents a fixed number. If you use the SD option, the measurement scale of the numerical value refers to the measurement scale of the standardized variable.

arguments.name: level
arguments.description: Assigns the level of the corresponding classification variable that is specified in the var-key, where level represents an actual character level of the variable.

arguments.name: CLABEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a short content-label for the mediation effects that are generated by the EVALUATE statement. The clabel is used to label the corresponding set of tables in the output. Only the first 20 characters of clabel is used. If you do not specify this option, the first 20 characters of the label, which you specify in the beginning of the EVALUATE statement, is used as clabel.

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: specifies the type of decompositions requested, where i is between 2 and 4, representing two-, three-, or four-way decompositions, respectively.

arguments.name: NODECOMP
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of all decomposition results for the specified evaluation scheme of mediation effects. Only the summary table of effects is shown.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: If a variable in the data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other values in the observation, include the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. The procedure then treats the data set as if each observation appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. The total number of observations is considered to be equal to the sum of the FREQ variable values when the procedure determines degrees of freedom for significance probabilities.

statements.name: MEDIATOR
statements.description: The MEDIATOR statement is required for specifying the mediator model. You provide mediator (the name of the mediator variable) on the left of the equal sign and treatment (the name of the treatment variable) on the right. For example, the following statement specifies M as the mediator variable and T as the treatment variable in the analysis: mediator M = T; Together, the COVAR, MEDIATOR, and MODEL statements specify the relationships of all variables in the mediation analysis.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement is required for specifying the outcome model. You provide outcome (the name of the outcome variable) on the left of the equal sign and effects (the treatment and mediator effects) on the right.

arguments.name: DIST=
arguments.description: Specifies the built-in probability distribution to use in the model.

arguments.name: BIN
arguments.description: Binary distribution

arguments.name: NEGBIN
arguments.description: Negative binomial distribution

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: Normal distribution

arguments.name: POISSON
arguments.description: Poisson distribution

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the link function in the model.

arguments.name: IDENTITY
arguments.description: Identity link function

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Log link function

arguments.name: LOGIT
arguments.description: Logit link function
